title-group.article-title: Ameliorative effect of docosahexaenoic acid on 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin-induced histological changes, oxidative stress, and DNA damage in rat liver

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Biology, Atatürk University, Erzurum, Turkey
2Department of Environmental Studies, Institute of Graduate Studies and Research, Alexandria University, Alexandria, Egypt

author-notes.corresp: Fatime Geyikoglu, Department of Biology, Atatürk University, 25240 Erzurum, Turkey Email: geyikogluff@yahoo.com

abstract.p: 2,3,7,8-Tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin (TCDD) is an environmental contaminant that leads to the development of hepatotoxicity. Docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) has been proposed to counteract oxidative stress and improve antioxidant status, and several studies suggest that supplementations with antioxidants can influence hepatotoxicity. The aim of the current study was to explore the role of DHA in modulating the toxicity of TCDD in the liver of Sprague-Dawley rats. Animals were assigned to four groups (n = 5): control (only dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO)), 8 μg/kg body weight (b.w.) TCDD in DMSO solution; 250 mg/kg b.w. DHA and TCDD plus DHA; respectively. Rats were intraperitoneally administered their respective doses daily for 21 days. On day 21, the animals were killed, and then biochemical tests, pathological examination, and micronucleus (MN) assay were performed in the liver. Our results showed that the activities of antioxidant enzymes were significantly decreased and serious pathological findings were established in rats that received TCDD. Beside the rate of MNs in hepatocytes was increased after the treatment with dioxin. In rats treated with DHA alone, MNs were not changed and the activities of antioxidant enzymes were significantly increased. The presence of DHA with TCDD alleviated its pathological effects in hepatic tissue. DHA also prevented the suppression of antioxidant enzymes in the livers of animals exposed to TCDD and displayed a strong protective effect against MNs. It can be concluded that DHA has beneficial influences and could be able to antagonize TCDD toxicity in liver.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: 2,3,7,8-Tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin (TCDD) is an environmental contaminant that elicits a broad-spectrum of toxic effects in a species-specific manner (Dere et al., 2011). It displays a wide-spectrum of toxic effects, including dermal toxicity, developmental and reproductive toxicity, immunotoxicity, hepatotoxicity, carcinogenicity, teratogenicity, neurobehavioral, endocrine, and metabolic alterations (Gan et al., 2009; Hung et al., 2006; Li et al., 2010; Xu et al., 2008; Yin et al., 2011). The relative potencies for TCDD have been reported in previous studies (Van den Berg et al., 1998). The studies have suggested that these effects are mediated by the aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AhR), and oxidative stress is an important constituent in the mechanism of TCDD toxicity. The exposures of mice and rats to different doses of TCDD have resulted in increases in the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS), lipid peroxidation (LP), and DNA damage (Aly and Khafagy, 2011; Ciftci et al., 2011; Hassoun et al., 2000; Reyes-Hernànde et al., 2010). Hence, TCDD has been shown to be responsible for multisite cancers in experimental animals (Bock, 1994; Grassman et al., 1998; Shiizaki et al., 2008). TCDD is also a potent promoter of cancer in liver (Huff et al., 1994). However, in vivo and in vitro studies of human and animal cells have provided inconsistent findings of genetic toxicity of TCDD. On the other hand, there are equivocal findings of chromosomal aberrations in humans exposed in vivo to TCDD (IARC, 1997) and increased production of 8-oxo-2-deoxyguanosine (8-OH-dG) in the liver of mice (Hung et al., 2006). Recently, it is reported that dioxin-like chemicals alter expression of numerous genes in liver, but it remains unknown which lie in pathways leading to major toxicities such as hepatotoxicity, wasting, and lethality (Forgacs et al., 2010; Moffat et al., 2010).

Docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) is an omega 3 fatty acid. Oils from cold-water fish are rich in n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids, in particular DHA (Eicher and McVey 1995; Wertz, 2009). Evidence presented over the past 20 years has shown that long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acids especially the DHA is beneficial for health (Kruger et al., 2010). Diets rich in n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids have been associated with a reduced risk of several types of cancer (Slagsvold et al., 2010). Dietary DHA also reduced the risk of heart disease in humans (Weitz et al., 2010). DHA plays an important role in fetal and infant brain development, including neurocognitive and neuromotor functions (Harper et al., 2011; Su, 2010). This fatty acid can act as hepatoprotective agent (Chen et al., 2011; Roy et al., 2007). In the last years, there is a renewed interest in the biological activities of DHA (Bergè and Barnathan, 2005). It has therapeutic properties, such as antimicrobial (Martinez et al., 2009), anti-inflammatory, immunomodulatory (Gapeyev et al., 2011), antioxidant (Arnal et al., 2009; Castillo et al., 2011), and antitumor (Dupertuis et al., 2007) activities, among others. Despite the valuable biological activities however, it always demonstrates considerable biological activity, especially antioxidant activity (Takayama et al., 2010). DHA concentration-dependently scavenges the intracellular radical production induced by oxidative or hypoxic stress (Shimazawa et al., 2009). For this reason, it attracts the attention of scientists in the search for new therapeutic usage. Antioxidants play an important role in inhibiting and scavenging free radicals, thus providing protection to humans against infectious and degenerative diseases (Nader et al., 2010). According to the above-mentioned data, TCDD is involved in the production of hepatic oxidative stress and supplementation with DHA may protect the animals from the harmful effects of TCDD. The role of DHA against TCDD-induced hepatotoxicity has not so far been studied. Therefore, the objectives of the study were to (1) investigate alterations in antioxidant enzyme activities and micronucleus (MN) rates and also examine liver histopathology by induced TCDD; (2) investigate the effect of DHA alone; and (3) investigate the role of DHA in alleviating the negative effects of TCDD.

sec.title: Animals
sec.p: Experiments were performed on male Sprague-Dawley rats, 8-week-old, weighing 165–190 g. The animals were kept on a 12-h light–dark cycle and allowed free access to food and water. All experiments were performed in accordance with the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals (National Research Council, 1996). The study was approved by the local ethics committee.

sec.title: Experimental design
sec.p: The animals were randomly divided into four equal groups: (1) controls (only DMSO), (2) rats that received 8 μg/kg body weight (b.w.) TCDD (CAS No. 1746-01-6, Sigma-Aldrich®, St. Louis, MO, USA) intraperitoneally (ip) for 21 days; (3) rats that received 250 mg/kg b.w. DHA (CAS No. 6217-54-5, Sigma-Aldrich®, USA) ip for 21 days; and (4) rats treated simultaneously with TCDD and DHA for 21 days. The doses were selected according to the literature data (Czepiel et al., 2010; Nguyen et al., 1999). After the treatments with all chemicals, the animals were anesthetized with ether and liver samples were obtained. Liver tissues were separated into three portions. The first part was used for determination of antioxidant enzyme activities and glutathione (GSH) level, the second part was used for MN analysis, and the third part was used for histological examinations.

sec.title: Biochemical studies
sec.p: The tissue preparation was performed according to the procedure previously described by Skrzydlewska and Farbiszewski (1997). The liver samples placed in iced sodium chloride (NaCl) (0.15 M) perfused with the same solution in order to remove the blood cells, then blotted on filter paper, weighed and homogenized in 9 vol of ice-cold 0.25 M sucrose and 0.15 M NaCl with addition of 6 pl of 250 mM BHT in ethanol to prevent the formation of peroxides during the assay. The homogenization procedure was performed under standardized conditions. Homogenates (10%) were centrifuged at 10,000g for 15 min at 4°C, and the supernatant was kept on ice until assayed. The protein content in the liver was measured by the method of Lowry et al. (1951). Superoxide dismutase (SOD) activity in supernatant was measured according to the method of Misra and Fridovich (1972). The catalase (CAT) activities of liver tissues were measured according to the method of Aebi (1984). The activity of GSH peroxidase (GSH-Px) in the liver was determined according to the method of Lawrence and Burk (1976). The measurement of GSH in liver tissue was performed as described by Akerboom and Sies (1981).

sec.title: Liver MN assay
sec.p: Liver MN assay was done using the method of Suzuki et al. (2009). Isolated hepatocytes from rats were prepared by the collagenase perfusion technique (Wang et al., 2002). Liver was perfused through the hepatic portal vein with calcium-free Hank’s balanced salt solution to remove blood for about 10 min at a flow rate of 2.5 ml/min. As soon as the liver become grayish brown in color, a second buffer solution containing collagenase (Hank’s balanced salt supplemented with 4 mM calcium chloride and 0.5 mg collagenase/ml) was perfused at the same rate until the liver appeared to have broken up. Then the liver was minced into 3- to 4-mm pieces with a sterile scalpel. Following mechanical dissociation, the cells were filtered through gauze and centrifuged at 1350 rpm for 5 min. The hepatocyte pellets were suspended in 10% neutral-buffered formalin and stored under refrigeration. Immediately prior to evaluation, 10–20 μl of hepatocyte suspension was mixed with an equal volume of acridine orange (AO)–4′,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole dihydrochloride (DAPI) stain solution (AO, 0.5 mg/ml; DAPI, 10 μg/ml) for fluorescent staining. Approximately 10–20 μl of the mixture was dropped onto a glass slide and covered with a cover glass. Samples of well-isolated hepatocytes were evaluated with the aid of a fluorescence microscope counting the number of micronucleated hepatocytes (MNHEPs) in 2000 hepatocytes for each animal. MNHEPs were defined as hepatocytes with round or distinct MNs that stained like the nucleus, with a diameter one-fourth or less than that of the nucleus and confirmed by focusing up and down, taking hepatocyte thickness into account.

sec.title: Histological studies
sec.p: Rats were killed by ether and immediately dissected. Livers were used for slide preparations. The liver samples were fixed in 10% formaldehyde and were embedded in paraffin for microscopic examination. Later, sections obtained from paraffin blocks (5 μm) were stained with hematoxylin–eosin (HE).

sec.title: Statistics
sec.p: The experimental data were analyzed using one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) and Fischer’s least significant difference (LSD) tests to determine whether any treatment significantly differed from the controls or each other. Results presented as mean ± SD values and the level of 0.05 was regarded statistically significant.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: TCDD (8 μg/kg b.w.) caused significant (p < 0.05) decreases in the hepatic antioxidant activities of SOD, CAT, GSH-Px enzymes and GSH content in the liver of rats. On the contrary, the animals treated with DHA alone showed significant increases in the levels of GSH and in the activities of antioxidant enzymes. Furthermore, application of DHA significantly (p < 0.05) increased the reduced antioxidant enzyme activities by TCDD (Table 1).

caption.p: Alterations in the activities of superoxide dismutase (SOD), catalase (CAT), glutathione peroxidase (GSH-Px), and the level of reduced glutathione (GSH) in the liver of rats treated with DHA (250 mg/kg b.w.), TCDD (8 µg/kg b.w.), and their combinationa

fn.p: b.w.: body weight, TCDD: 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin, DHA: docosahexaenoic acid.
aEach value represents mean ± SD of five animals; means in the same column followed by the different superscript letters present significant differences at the p < 0.05 level.

sec.p: The results of the liver MN assay in Sprague-Dawley rats are shown in Table 2. TCDD (8 μg/kg b.w.) induced a statistically significant increase in the formation of MNHEPs, although DHA did not change the MNHEPs number as compared to the control group. Moreover, DHA reduced the increased MNHEPs rates by TCDD.

caption.p: Results of liver MN assay in rats treated with DHA (250 mg/kg b.w.), TCDD (8 µg/kg b.w.), and their combinationa

fn.p: b.w.: body weight, DHA: docosahexaenoic acid, HEP: hepatocyte; MN: micronucleus, MNHEPs: micronucleated hepatocytes, TCDD: 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin.
aEach value represents mean ±SD of five animals; means in the same column followed by the different superscript letters present significant differences at the p < 0.05 level.

sec.p: Microscopic examination showed liver parenchyma consisting of hepatocytes in control rats. Sinusoids and central vein were also clearly visible (Figure 1). The DHA compared to the controls did not lead to any histopathologic finding in liver samples (data not shown). On the contrary, the livers in TCDD-treated group revealed severe pathological damages such as parenchymal degenerations, sinusoidal dilatation, lymphocyte infiltration, and lipid accumulation (Figure 2a and b). On the other hand, our results pointed out that the treatment of DHA provided to decrease the liver damages. However, the livers showed sinusoidal dilatations at different degrees (more or less) (Figure 3).

caption.p: The liver of control rats. Sinusoid (arrows), central vein ((CV) hematoxylin–eosin (HE), ×68).

The liver of 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin (TCDD)-treated rats. (a) Sinusoidal dilatations (double arrows), lymphocyte infiltration (L), and parenchymal degenerations (arrows); (b) lymphocyte infiltration (L) and lipid accumulation (arrow; hematoxylin–eosin (HE), ×68).
The livers of rats after the combined treatments with 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin (TCDD) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA). Sinusoidal dilatations (arrows; hematoxylin–eosin (HE), ×68).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: TCDD increases oxidative stress in hepatic and brain tissues of rat (Ciftci et al., 2011; Hassoun et al., 2000; Shertzer, 2010). And the greater expression of oxidative stress in liver exposed to TCDD may be due to inactivation of the antioxidant enzymes (Jin et al., 2008). Our study clearly demonstrates that a decreased ability to scavenge ROS may result from TCDD exposure, contributing to oxidative stress and thus to the hepatotoxicity of TCDD. Recent studies indicate that the oxidative stress develops when the levels of antioxidants are lowered (Banudevi et al., 2005; Tapiero et al., 2004; Yilmaz et al., 2011). Individual antioxidants can be very sensitive in revealing a pro-oxidant stressor (Regoli and Winston, 1999). And it is emphasized that the antioxidants (both enzymatic and nonenzymatic) play a central role in cellular oxidant defense systems that protect cells against damage induced by free radicals, such as superoxide anion and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) (Cerutti et al., 1994; Priya et al., 2011; Valko et al., 2005). In this study, GSH is significantly lowered in TCDD-treated rat hepatocytes. GSH is one of the most abundant intracellular antioxidants in animal cells (Kidd, 1997). It detoxifies endogenous ROS and/or exogenous oxidative damage (Vina, 1990). In mice, exposure to TCDD results in a significant depletion of GSH by oxidative stress in liver (Slezak et al., 2000). GSH is only one part of the antioxidant defense system in the liver because there is abundant SOD and CAT in the liver. Therefore, TCDD toxicity can be decreased by SOD and CAT in neutralizing ROS (Wiseman and Chow, 2000). In our study, TCDD exposure also causes a significant suppression of the activities of the protective endogenous enzymes SOD, CAT, and GSH-Px in the liver. And SOD shows whether oxidative stress is developed by TCDD. SOD is the primary step of the defense mechanism in the antioxidant system against oxidative stress. It catalyses the dismutation of two superoxide radicals (O2 −) into molecular oxygen (O2) and H2O2 (Fouchecourt and Riviere, 1995; Kakarla et al., 2005). Endogenous H2O2 may be converted into H2O by CAT (Svistunenko, 2005). CAT activity is also decreased in hepatocytes during TCDD treatment and its activity is inhibited by the superoxide radical (Kono and Fridovich, 1982). The suppression of these enzyme activities has been linked to induction of oxidative stress and hepatotoxicity (El-Tawil and Elsaieed, 2005; Latchoumycandane et al., 2003). In addition, we have demonstrated that key antioxidant enzyme, GSH-Px, is suppressed by TCDD in rat liver. The observed decreases in GSH-related enzyme activities indicate that TCDD may induce oxidative stress in rat liver by altering GSH metabolic mechanisms at the cellular level (Twaroski et al., 2003). GSH-Px can protect DNA and lipids of the cell against peroxidation products (Bukowska, 2004). The observed decline in the activity of GSH-Px in TCDD-treated hepatocytes may be ascribed to the reduction in the level of the GSH and an increase in the level of peroxides (Twaroski et al., 2003). Thus, the balance of this enzyme system may be essential to remove superoxide anion and peroxides generated in hepatocytes.

In humans and rodents, a mode of action of TCDD involves events that stem from the initial binding of TCDD to the aryl or aromatic hydrocarbon (Ah) receptor. The Ah receptor is an intracellular protein that acts as a signal transducer and activator for gene transcription (DeVito et al., 1995; Safe, 1990). Besides, it is suggested that the relative potency of TCDD in cells may be modulated by binding to other proteins (DeVito et al., 1997). This study supports that the TCDD toxicity is highly correlated with the decreasing antioxidant enzyme activities in liver. In present study, the decreased antioxidant status may be due to TCDD-induced protein carbonylation in rat hepatocytes as a result of oxidative stress or direct inhibition of the enzyme activities by ROS. The protein damage may cause the decline in enzyme activities of the antioxidant system and probably the electron transporting system, then leading to excessive ROS generation in hepatocytes (Meister and Anderson, 1983).

TCDD-induced oxidative stress causes single-strand breaks in DNA from liver and brain tissues of rats (Hassoun et al., 2000, 2001). In our investigation, MN test is performed for the first time and is revealed that TCDD exposure increases the rate of MNs in hepatocytes. MN assay is a reliable test indicating the chromosomal damage (Yılmaz et al., 2008), and MN production is one of the key pieces of evidence for the possible involvement of antioxidant activity in oxidative DNA damage (Tung-Kwang et al., 2010; Turkez et al., 2010). ROS can alter vital cell components such as polyunsaturated fatty acids, proteins, and nucleic acids (Halliwell and Gutteridge, 1990). The increased production of ROS, LP, and DNA and membrane damage are always associated with TCDD exposure (Hung et al., 2006; Shertzer et al., 1998). In present study, the high dose of TCDD also elicits severe instances of liver damage (hepatocyte degeneration, lymphocyte infiltration, sinusoidal dilatation, and lipid accumulation) when compared to the low dose of TCDD. It is reported that the pathological effects in hepatic tissue of TCDD may lead to disruption in the functional integrity of hepatocytes (Boverhof et al., 2006; Czepiel et al., 2010; Kopec et al., 2010). Thus, TCDD is known to be responsible for the carcinogenic effects associated with oxidative DNA damage (Hung et al., 2006). Studies have been carried out on the role of antioxidant components in the detoxification of TCDD, and it has been established that limited efficacy of Ah receptor agonists unable to provide sufficient protection without using antioxidants (Hung et al., 2006). In this study, DHA alone significantly increases antioxidant enzyme activities. Moreover, DHA, which has not previously been used as detoxifier, is demonstrated to display beneficial effects on MNs, by returning their values close to those of the control group after TCDD insult. This suggests the antioxidant activities of DHA.

Ambrozova et al. (2010) investigated the effect of DHA on the free radical and they found that DHA exhibits antioxidant effect. Some authors have underlined the occurrence of alterations in enzyme activities (Kim and Chung, 2007). DHA has been tested for the galactosamine-induced liver damage in mice and the obtained results indicated that DHA is able to present hepatoprotective effects (Roy et al., 2007). Also, protective effect of DHA was determined on cholestatic liver injury (Chen et al., 2011). Similarly, results suggested that DHA protected the liver of rats against methyl mercury-induced toxicity and provide evidence that it has therapeutic potential as hepatoprotective agent (Jin et al., 2007). In present study, the DHA has a pronounced effect on the relative potency of TCDD. Noteworthy, it prevents liver damages (except for sinusoidal dilatations). Taken together these findings constitute evidence that the antioxidative properties of the DHA contribute to the prevention of hepatocyte degenerations and hepatic DNA damages induced by TCDD in rats, and this suggests that changes in enzyme activities are related to decrease in oxidative stress. Because effective antioxidants are free radical scavengers that interfere with radical chain reactions, it is possible to protect cellular DNA from oxidative stress by supplementation with antioxidants (Lee et al., 2010).

In summary, our data clearly show that TCDD induces generation of MNs and hepatocyte toxicity by a mechanism involving oxidative stress. Our results show that DHA is a promising source for the development of potential protectors against TCDD-induced oxidative stress and, especially, against MNs; thus, it may reduce the risk of carcinogenesis in liver. Because of its effects on antioxidant enzymes of DHA, this finding may provide new insight into the development of therapeutic and preventive approaches in TCDD toxicity.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
